bestBHT.bht: The Israelites, as a collective, provoked God through their unbelief, leading to their exclusion from entering His rest. This warning against apostasy urges us to consider who provoked God and reminds us that a good beginning does not guarantee a good ending. Many of God's chosen people failed to reach the Promised Land due to their disobedience, ultimately perishing in their sin. Let us be cautious against unbelief and draw inspiration from the faithful few who remained devoted to God in the midst of adversity.

Henry Alford: The faithful exceptions are overlooked, and the whole of Israel is included in the provocation, to make the exhortation fall more forcibly on the readers.
You need indeed to be careful against unbelief:—for on account of this very unbelief all our fathers were excluded.
And to whom sware He that they should not enter into His rest, except to those who disobeyed.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For WHO was it that, when they had heard (referring to 'if ye will hear,') did provoke (God)?
The 'For' implies, Ye need to take heed against unbelief: for, was it not because of unbelief that all our fathers were excluded?
'Nay (why need I put the question?), was it not all that came out of Egypt?'
Albert Barnes: The truth was that a large proportion of them rebelled against God, and provoked him to indignation.
Like the Hebrews who heard God speak from Mount Sinai, it is possible that those who witness the mercies of God in redemption may be in danger of abusing all those mercies and perishing.
The exception [of those who did not rebel] was so small that the apostle had no scruple in saying in general that they were all rebellious.
Marvin Vincent: My warning against apostasy is not superfluous or irrelevant: for, consider: who were they that provoked God?
They were those who had fairly begun their journey to Canaan, as you have begun your Christian course. They provoked God, so may you.
So far from its being true that a good ending necessarily follows a good beginning, a whole generation of God's chosen people failed to reach the Land of Promise because they provoked God.
John Calvin: The apostle mentions this to modify what had been more severely said by David, in order that we may know that the word is preached to all for this end, that all may obey it with one consent.
The whole people were justly condemned for unbelief when the body was torn and mutilated by the defection of the greatest part.
As God forbids you to follow the unbelief of the fathers, so he sets before you other fathers whose faith is to be your example.
Archibald T. Robertson: Did provoke (παρεπικραναν). First aorist active indicative of παραπικρινω, apparently coined by the LXX like παραπικρασμος (verse Hebrews 3:15) to which it points, exasperating the anger of God.

Nay, did not all (αλλ' ου παντες). 'A favourite device of the diatribe style' (Moffatt), answering one rhetorical question with another (Luke 17:8) as in verses Hebrews 3:17; Hebrews 3:18, There was a faithful minority mentioned by Paul (1 Corinthians 10:7).
John Gill: The aggravation of their sin is, that they did it when they had heard the Gospel, and while they were hearing it; which shows that the Gospel may be heard to no advantage.
Hence the Gospel heard, comes to be an aggravation of men's condemnation.
God will have a few to serve him in the worst of times.
John Wesley: An awful consideration! The whole elect people of God (a very few excepted) provoked God presently after their great deliverance..."
The whole elect people of God... continued to grieve his Spirit for forty years...

bhtAttempts.bht: The Israelites, as a collective, provoked God to the point of exclusion from His rest because of their unbelief. This warning against apostasy is not irrelevant, as it is crucial to consider who provoked God. The majority of God's chosen people failed to reach the Land of Promise because of their disobedience and exasperation of God's anger. This serves as a sobering reminder that a good beginning does not necessarily ensure a good ending, as demonstrated by the whole generation that perished in their sin. So, let us be careful against unbelief and follow the example of those few faithful ones who served God in the worst of times.

The collective unbelief of the Israelites led to their exclusion from God's rest. Their provocation of God serves as a warning against apostasy, highlighting the importance of considering who provoked Him. The majority failed to reach the Land of Promise due to their disobedience and exasperation of God's anger. This should remind us that a good beginning doesn't guarantee a good ending, as demonstrated by the generation that perished in their sin. Let us be cautious against unbelief and learn from the faithful few who served God faithfully.

The Israelites, through their unbelief and provocation of God, were collectively excluded from entering His rest. This serves as a warning against apostasy and emphasizes the importance of considering who provoked God. The majority failed to reach the Promised Land due to their disobedience, causing them to perish in their sin. It is a reminder that a good beginning does not guarantee a good ending. Let us be cautious against unbelief and learn from the faithful few who served God faithfully.

The Israelites, as a collective, provoked God through their unbelief, leading to their exclusion from entering His rest. This warning against apostasy urges us to consider who provoked God and reminds us that a good beginning does not guarantee a good ending. Many of God's chosen people failed to reach the Promised Land due to their disobedience, ultimately perishing in their sin. Let us be cautious against unbelief and draw inspiration from the faithful few who remained devoted to God in the midst of adversity.

The collective unbelief of the Israelites caused God to exclude them from His rest. This serves as a warning against apostasy and reminds us that a good beginning does not guarantee a good ending. Most of God's chosen people were disobedient and provoked Him, resulting in their failure to enter the Promised Land and their subsequent perishing. Let us be cautious against unbelief and take inspiration from the few faithful ones who served God amidst adversity.
